Plastic coating actually involves a kinda similar process.
Plastic powder is poured in a fluidiser and the fluidisation process makes the powder become fluid-like for even coating of metal.

If you notice the dust coming out of your successful bucket that is pure silica. Silicosis is a non-reversible breathing condition caused by breathing dust. Yes it takes years of breathing it usually BUT it is cumulative and decreases your ability to breathe gradually. My point is wear a mask or avoid breathing dust as much as possible.

Fluidization also occurs in water treatment where you fludize the filter beds to clean them during the backwash cycle where water and sometimes air are forced through the bed from the bottom to wash away the particles trapped by the sand and anthracite filters.  If you lose somethng heavy (like a steel clamp) during a backwash it will end up buried under several feet of filter media, filter media that you can walk on when the bed isn't fluidized.

If you have ever worked with fiberglass or composites you may have used Cabosil or a similar potting compound.  I think the correct name for it is Thixotropic Silica but I'm probably wrong.  Cabosil is used as a filler in some toothpastes as well but the coolest thing is that it almost behaves like water.  I used to have some in a jar and when you shake it up or twirl it around inside the jar it looked just like water.  Maybe that would make an interesting substitution for sand in your experiment.

This is a good example of how quicksand works, only with water as the working fluid. Place your hand in while operating then turn off the air and your hand is trapped proportional to the volume of sand above it. This is what makes quicksand so dangerous as your body blocks the fluid flow that keeps the sand suspended, the sand settles around you, solidifies and tends to cause you to sink as your combined particle density is too great to float. If deep enough the result is not good.
 This is also how an avalanche works. Once the snow starts moving it is suspended in a sort of cloud of snow and entrained air. If the speed is great enough, and it doesn't take much, you will be carried along within the cloud until it stops. At that point the snow settles into a mass again and if you happen to not be at the surface, and because of your density compared to the cloud you probably won't be, well you can guess the result. If you didn't impact something on your trip you will suffocate from either the weight preventing you from breathing or CO2 accumulation.

We use this principle in wound care, too!  "An air-fluidized support surface employs the circulation of filtered air through silicone-coated ceramic beads, creating the characteristics of fluid. Fluidization is also used to evenly coat hot metal with a meltable material. A hot material is dropped into the bed made up of the meltable particles and they melt onto the part and then cool in the bed. this gives the part an amazing uniform coating with no drip areas or flat spots (from resting while cooling).

This is like liquefaction that occurs during earthquakes. Which is what happened on a major scale here in Christchurch, New Zealand, during our more significant quakes of over 5.5 magnitude. It was a fascinating process to see the land sliding around. The city is on top of old swamp land which is predominantly, a very fine sand. Once it was wet from various water supplies including damaged sewage lines, it became very heavy and dense.
PS: The first significant quake occurred in September 2010 and we got another aftershock two nights ago. Seven years of this. It was only a 3.3 magnitude though, so no damage or hurts thankfully.

A fluidized bed (literally a bed of fine glass sand with air bubbles) is used in treatment of burn patients in specialised hospitals. And it is probably a great idea for burn-treatment, because when a patient's most of the skin is burnt, doesn't matter how you put him in bed, always some burnt areas will contact the mattress and will not heal as easily as air-exposed skin. So some scientists (probably japanese) had this idea to make an air bed where all the skin will be floating on air, without touching a permanent surface, and they made these beds. I was shocked by the genius idea when I first saw those beds in a burn-clinic in Russia 10-12 years ago, they were purchased from Japan. It looked something like this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4WLeAb6lYG0

1) Joined edx

3)Silicosis (previously miner's phthisis, grinder's asthma, potter's rot and other occupation-related names) is a form of occupational lung disease caused by inhalation of crystalline silica dust, and is marked by inflammation and scarring in the form of nodular lesions in the upper lobes of the lungs.
4)Maybe running compressed air thru "Particularized sand,allowing it to become airborne for even easier inhalation " maybe not so cool. On your very first try,you did infact cause microscopic lesions in you respiratory tract and lung's.
5) I learned this the hard way. Used an out door type sand blaster "Once" without a respirator. Now thats like the nuclear version of your experiment here,but still. I did learn that not even dust mask help. It needs to be a sealed filter rated to single out Particulates. Think of Volcanic glass. Pretty sure its the sharpest substance's on the planet. I've discovered that laser toner (very fine powder) acts a lot like a liquid just by agitating it a little. No air flow needed.

For the air injection part of the experiment, the resistance of the air through the manifold/diffuser needs to be an order of magnitude higher than the resistance of the air through the fluidized medium. Otherwise the difference in resistance between solid sand and fluidized sand produces a very clear "path of least resistance" that all the air ends up going through.
